info.title: Laboperator API
info.description:
This is the Laboperator API documentation bundled with
your Laboperator Server. It will reflect the API v2 subversion that
runs on this instance.

# PRE-RELEASE
The current distribution of the API v2 is a pre-realease and as such
subject to frequent updates and potentially breaking changes.

# Changelog
This changelog will be kept here for pre-releases only.

## v2.0.0-rc.14
### Changed
- replace archival (deleted and deleted_at) with hiding (hidden_at)

### Removed
- removed endpoints for `protocol_rules`

## v2.0.0-rc.13
### Added
- additional endpoints for `applications`, `attachments`, `authentications`, `automations`, `collections`, `comments`,
  `connectors` enrollments, `dashboards`, `device_classes`, `exports`, `organisations`, `samples`, `secrets` and `secret_acceses`,
  `signatures`, `smart_views`, `update_requests`, `versions`, `webhook_logs`, `workflow_events`, `workflow_fields`, `workflow_runs`,
  `workflow_steps`, `workflow_step_templates`, `workflow_templates`

### Changed
- this API documentation is now publicly available without needing to authenticate
- restore endpoint on various resources now works on singular resource instead of collection

### Removed
- removed obsolete attributes from `device_types` endpoint
- removed endpoints for `jobs`, and, `tasks`

## v2.0.0-rc.12
### Added
- introduce trait-tags in API V2 documentaion for common query parameters `fields`, `filter`, `sort`, `page`

### Changed
- API V2 data_points endpoints are normalized

## v2.0.0-rc.11

### Added
- additional endpoints for `jobs`, `views`, `tasks`, `notifications`, `ports`, `schemas`
- custom rake task `rake spec:api_v2_docs` for running specs along with generation of documentation
- `filter` fetch parameter accepts and understands comparison operators `gt`, `ge`, `lt`, `le`, `eq`, `ne`, `lk`, `nlk`

### Changed
- invalid query params are not ignored anymore but throw a 'Bad Request' error

### Fixed
- ActiveRecord validation errors are handled by JsonApiUtils
- `fields` specs context and descriptions
- errors which happen on a middleware level are handled in a JsonApiUtils manner

## v2.0.0-rc.10

### Changed
- invalid query params are not ignored anymore but throw a 'Bad Request' error

### Fixed
- ActiveRecord validation errors are handled by JsonApiUtils

## v2.0.0-rc.9

### Changed
- updated schema structure

### Fixed
- missing id parameter for device command endpoint
- minor errors in several response and body schemas

## v2.0.0-rc.8

### Added
- command execution endpoints
- devices command endpoint

## v2.0.0-rc.7

### Added
- protocol rule endpoints

## v2.0.0-rc.6

### Added
- data points endpoints
- task include `result`
- measurement `data_points` documentation
- measurement `protocol_entries` documentation

### Fixed
- task type serialization

## v2.0.0-rc.5

### Added
- support for filters
- support for sparse field sets
- Task.parameters documentation
- custom attributes documentation
- Job.response
- Task include option for Measurements
- added `created_at`, `description`, `end_at`, `protocol_entries`, `start_at`, `status`, `updated_at`, `uuid` to Measurement serializer

### Fixed
- URLs in links for subtyped entities

### Removed
- create action for channels
- `prev` and `next` links without logical relation (most cases as of now)

# Standards
The API uses standards (referenced below) and best practices to
make the interaction as easy as possible. Not only are standards
a great way of benefitting from the collective experience of a large
community that develops these standards, but also for users to rely
on a vivid ecosystem of documentation and resources.

## OpenAPI specification
This API is documented in the both human- and machine-readable
[OpenAPI](https://github.com/OAI/OpenAPI-Specification) format.
You can download the raw OpenAPI document for this API using the
button on the top of this page.

The OpenAPI specification originates from the
[swagger.io](https://swagger.io). There is an active community
around the standard and many [tools](https://openapi.tools)
available for most modern programming environments.

## JSON:API specification
While OpenAPI specifies how to document an API,
[JSON:API](https://jsonapi.org) is a specification for building APIs in
[JSON](https://www.json.org). It is mostly a set of conventions that help
us to build a consistent service. Our developers and users of the API
alike can build on generalized tooling and a common understanding of
what to expect.

schema.title: Workflow Event Schema
schema.description: A modification event done during a workflow execution.

add-step.title: AddStep Event
add-step.description:
The event of adding a step to a running dynamic template.
The added step will be appended as the last step of the run.

oneOf.description: Payload for externally defined step template
Payload of locally defined step template

move-step.title: MoveStep Event
move-step.description:
The event of moving a step in a running dynamic template.
Only steps which are not yet started can be moved.

remove-step.title: RemoveStep Event
remove-step.description:
The event of removing a step from a running dynamic template.
Only steps which are not yet started can be removed

resolve-if.title: ResolveIf Event
resolve-if.description:
The event of resolving the condition in an `if` flow of steps.

If the condition resolves to a truthy value, the steps included in `then` will be unfolded.
Otherwise, the steps included in `else` will be unfolded.

If `else` is not specified in the `if` flow and the condition resolves to a falsy value,
no steps will be unfolded.

resolve-until.title: ResolveUntil Event
resolve-until.description:
The event of resolving the condition in a `loop-until` flow of steps.

If the condition in `until` resolves to a falsy value, the steps included in `loop` will be unfolded.
Otherwise, the execution will break out of the `loop-until` flow and continue to evaluate the next entry in the parent flow.

resolve-while.title: ResolveWhile Event
resolve-while.description:
The event of resolving the condition in a `while` flow of steps.

If the condition in `while` resolves to a truthy value, the steps included in `do` will be unfolded.
Otherwise, the execution will break out of the `while` flow and continue to evaluate the next entry in the parent flow.

resolve-for-each.title: ResolveForEach Event
resolve-for-each.description:
The event of resolving a single iteration of `for-each` flow of steps.

The iteration will continue up to and including the last item in the source array.

version.title: Version
version.description:
A version that is a valid version tag according to the
[Semantic Versioning 2.0.0](https://semver.org) Specification. We
encourage you to follow the SemVer guidelines:

Given a version number MAJOR.MINOR.PATCH, increment the:

1. MAJOR version when you make incompatible API changes,
2. MINOR version when you add functionality in a backwards-compatible
   manner, and
3. PATCH version when you make backwards-compatible bug fixes.

member-name.title: Member Name
member-name.description:
A member name that is used as a reference elsewhere.
Allowed characters are lower "a" to "z", capital "A" to "Z", "0" to "9" and
"-" , "_". We recommend to consistently use either lowerCamelCase or
kebab-case. While snake_case is allowed, it has a chance of name collisions
with internal values.

attributes.title: Test SOP 123
attributes.description:
## Test SOP 123
This our Test Workflow for the first milestone of the SmartLab Project.

### General features of Milestone 1
When you reached this point you have already figured out how to:

- upload a workflow template
- and open your template

And there is more to discover:

- uploading new versions of your template
- creating workflow runs from your template
- starting, pausing, resuming, closing and re-entering workflow runs

### Features covered in this workflow

- Different field types
- Markdown descriptions (like this one)
- Preparing fields, like selecting a device
- Basic sequential execution of steps
- Inline field references on substeps
- A general confirm button
- Navigation on step completion
- Manual Triggers, e.g. Buttons with
- Actions to
   1. repeat a step
   1. complete a substep
   1. send a device command (though we are lacking data capturing and representation of the results making this kinda lame)

### The Demo Flow
The workflow for this demo consists of only two steps being reused in a
sequential flow. In the template that looks like this:

```yml
flow:
  - weighing:
      title: First Weighing
      fieldMapping:
        targetWeightOne: target
  - weighing:
      title: Second Weighing
      fieldMapping:
        targetWeightTwo: target
  - demoStep
  - demoStep
```

### Markdown Support
This is the workflows main description text. Just like most descriptions
in the template it features [Markdown](). [Markdown]() is super simple
markup language that enables basic formatting and is unlike HTML well
readable as raw text and therefore well suited to be written in the
template files.

We can even do cool things like this:

<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/b1gnV9fsARU" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

[Markdown]: https://markdown.de

info.title: Test SOP 123
info.description:
## Test SOP 123
This our Test Workflow for the first milestone of the SmartLab Project.

### General features of Milestone 1
When you reached this point you have already figured out how to:

- upload a workflow template
- and open your template

And there is more to discover:

- uploading new versions of your template
- creating workflow runs from your template
- starting, pausing, resuming, closing and re-entering workflow runs

### Features covered in this workflow

- Different field types
- Markdown descriptions (like this one)
- Preparing fields, like selecting a device
- Basic sequential execution of steps
- Inline field references on substeps
- A general confirm button
- Navigation on step completion
- Manual Triggers, e.g. Buttons with
- Actions to
   1. repeat a step
   1. complete a substep
   1. send a device command (though we are lacking data capturing and representation of the results making this kinda lame)

### The Demo Flow
The workflow for this demo consists of only two steps being reused in a
sequential flow. In the template that looks like this:

```yml
flow:
  - weighing:
      title: First Weighing
      fieldMapping:
        targetWeightOne: target
  - weighing:
      title: Second Weighing
      fieldMapping:
        targetWeightTwo: target
  - demoStep
  - demoStep
```

### Markdown Support
This is the workflows main description text. Just like most descriptions
in the template it features [Markdown](). [Markdown]() is super simple
markup language that enables basic formatting and is unlike HTML well
readable as raw text and therefore well suited to be written in the
template files.

We can even do cool things like this:

<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/b1gnV9fsARU" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

[Markdown]: https://markdown.de

children.value: In the template this substep looks like this:

- primary: Place the {{sample}} on {{balance}}.
  confirm: true
In the template this substep looks like this:

- primary: Weigh {{target}} of {{sample}}.
  secondary: "Tolerance: {{tolerance}}"
  devices:
    - balance:
        image: https://uc.uxpin.com/files/681215/673367/image-cb80bf.png
  buttons:
    - label: Print
      key: print
  behaviors:
    - when:
        manual:
          key: print
      do:
        send_command:
          device: balance
          command: get_weight
You can complete this substep with a custom button.
In the template this substep looks like this:

- primary: You can complete this substep with a custom button.
  buttons:
    - label: Complete Substep
      key: complete-substep
  behaviors:
    - when:
        MANUAL:
          key: complete-substep
      do:
        - complete_substep
You can repeat the step with a custom button.
or confirm it using the confirm button to the right
In the template this substep looks like this:

- primary: You can repeat the step with a custom button.
  secondary: or confirm it using the confirm button to the right
  confirm: true
  buttons:
    - label: Repeat Step
      key: repeat-substep
  behaviors:
    - when:
        MANUAL:
          key: repeat-substep
      do:
        - repeat_step

parameters.description:
Any parameters send with the command including the command
that was triggered itself.

status.description:
There are four well defined status values:

- **sent:** The command was send to the device
- **confirmed:** The command was received by the device and will be processed
- **success:** The command has successfully been processed
- **error:** An error has occured whil processing the command

Additionally there might be other status values the device
sends after confirming the command and before finishing or
failing.

the command.

anyOf.description:
For the sake of efficiency the DataPoint entity is not a Resource Object as per the JSON:API specification.

A DataPoint is instead provided as a quadruple Array of `timestamp`, `value`, `str_value`, and `channel_id`.

The `timestamp` and the `channel_id` uniquely identify any data point.

Either `value` and `str_value` will always be `null` depending on the channel type.

**Note:** The order of the items is always as mentioned above,
which can due to limitations of the OpenApi specification not be expressed correctly in the schema.

oauth2.description:
All requests against the API need to be authenticated. We use
[OAuth 2.0](https://oauth.net/2/) to implement different
authentication strategies. If you are not familiar with OAuth,
yet, you can get started with some
[useful resources](https://oauth.net/articles/) to understand the
basics. All OAuth strategies lead to an Access Token being issued
that needs to be included in the headers of any API request.

For example:
```
Authorization: Bearer 6e5ca31a16a1bf3426b33ace25efd07d03afb1c63e5f5c0fb6e82ef8b0293a0d
```

### Prerequisites

Every third-party code that wants to authenticate against the API
needs to be registered as an OAuth Client or in the Laboperator
terminology an Application.

### OAuth Authorization Flows

The Laboperator API supports the following OAuth 2 authorization flows:

  - [Authorization Code](http://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-ietf-oauth-v2-22#section-4.1)
  - [Client Credentials](https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-ietf-oauth-v2-22#section-4.4)

`Authorization Code` will authorize requests as the Resource Owner, while `Client Credentials` flow, will authorize requests as the Application Owner.

tags.name: Fields
tags.description:
The `fields` parameter allows you to only fetch required information in
a query. It can be combined with other query parameters. By reducing the transferred

### Examples

- _return a single attribute:_ `devices?fields[devices]=name`
- _return multiple attributes:_ `devices?fields[devices]=name,created_at`
- _along with included resources:_ `devices?include=connector&fields[devices]=name&fields[connector]=name`

tags.name: Filtering
tags.description:
Filtering of resource's instances is available via a `filter` query
parameter. Can be combined with other query parameters.

### List of available comparison operators:

| Operator | Query Symbol |
|---|---|
| greater than ('>') | `gt` |
| greater or equal ('>=') | `ge` |
| less than ('<') | `lt` |
| less or equal ('<=') | `le` |
| equal (default) ('=') | `eq` |
| not equal ('!=') | `ne` |
| like (match at least partly) ('~*') | `lk` |
| unlike (does not match even partly) ('!~*') | `nlk` |
| match json objects ('@>') | `json` |
| null ('true or false') | `nil` |

### Examples

- `devices?filter[devices][status]=offline`
- _can be used on both the main resource and included:_ `devices?include=tasks&filter[devices][name]=DeviceName&filter[devices][status]=offline&filter[tasks][name]=SecondTask`
- _can be used with comparison operators:_ `tasks?filter[tasks][created_at][ge]=2014-01-01`.
- _can be used with null operator:_ `tasks?filter[tasks][completed_at][nil]=false`.

tags.name: Pagination
tags.description:
Pagination of resource's instances is available via a `page` query
parameter. Can be combined with other query paraters.

### Examples

- _number of pages to fetch:_ `devices?page[devices][number]=10`
- _number of records per page:_ `devices?page[devices][size]=2`
- _fetch the first page of records_ `devices?page[devices][size]=2&page[devices][first]`
- _fetch the last page of records_ `devices?page[devices][size]=2&page[devices][last]`
- _fetch the next page of records_ `devices?page[devices][size]=2&page[devices][next]`
- _fetch the previous page of records_ `devices?page[devices][size]=2&page[devices][prev]`
- _show the total number of available pages:_ `devices?page[devices][total]`

tags.name: Searching
tags.description:
Full-text search of resource's instances is available via a `search` query
parameter. Can be combined with other query parameters.

### Examples

- _search users:_ `users?search[users]=John%20engineer`
- _search collections:_ `collections?search[collections]=main%20project`
- _search devices:_ `devices?search[devices]=online`

tags.name: Sorting
tags.description:
Sorting of resource's instances is available via a `sort` query
parameter. Can be combined with other query parameters.

### Examples

- _sort in an ascending order by a given attribute:_ `devices?sort[devices]=created_at`
- _sort in a descending order by a given attribute:_ `devices?sort[devices]=-created_at`
- _accepts multiple attributes:_ `sort[devices]=-created_at,name`

tags.name: command_executions
tags.description:
A command execution is created for every command send to a device. If
the driver supports it the execution will also track confirmation and
completion or failure of the command.
